thread.title: Why Three Undocumented Students Are Suing Missouri Colleges for Higher Tuition Rates
thread.title_full: Why Three Undocumented Students Are Suing Missouri Colleges for Higher Tuition Rates

author: Cosmopolitan.com
title: Why Three Undocumented Students Are Suing Missouri Colleges for Higher Tuition Rates
text:
The ACLU is suing the University of Missouri Board of Curators, St. Louis Community College, and Metropolitan Community College of Kansas City on behalf of three undocumented students who say they were wrongly charged out-of-state tuition after a new state law passed, Fox News Latino reports .
All three students, who have not been identified and are only referred to as "Jane Doe" and "John Doe" in the lawsuit, were brought to the U.S. as babies and are legally in the country on Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA), which allows eligible undocumented immigrants who arrived in the U.S. before their 16th birthday and before 2007 to be exempt from deportation and to receive a renewable work permit. (It doesn't provide citizenship, but it does allow for temporary legal status.)
 The lawsuit argues that each student was eligible for in-district or in-state tuition but was instead charged the higher out-of-state tuition at each of their respective colleges. According to KCUR , the lawsuit is challenging the preamble to a new law that forbids public universities and colleges from using public money to provide in-state tuition to undocumented students. However, because that specific language appears in the preamble, not the body of the bill itself, the suit alleges that it's unenforceable.

One of the students, who lives in Independence, Missouri, and attended Metropolitan Community College of Kansas City (MCC), said that when he started at MCC, his tuition was $95 per credit; when it was raised to the out-of-state tuition of $225 per credit, he had to drop out, because he couldn't afford it. KCUR reports that he had been a high school athlete who had worked for years at a bank to save money to attend college, and he arrived in the U.S. when he was just 1 year old.
While spokespeople for the University of Missouri and St. Louis Community College declined to comment on the situation, MCC spokesperson Christina Medina said in a statement to FNL that the school "is committed to serving students and our community within the confines of the regulatory parameters provided by state and federal requirements."
